title: Contribute
text:
Contribute

Overall guidance on contributing to a PyAnsys library appears in the
Contributing topic
in the PyAnsys developer’s guide. Ensure that you are thoroughly familiar
with this guide before attempting to contribute to PyConceptEV.

The following contribution information is specific to PyConceptEV.

title: Contribute > Install in developer mode
text:
Install in developer mode

Installing PyConceptEV in developer mode allows you to modify and enhance
the source.

Clone the repository and move into it:

Create a fresh-clean Python environment and activate it:

Make sure that you have the latest required build system and documentation, testing,
and CI tools:

Install the project in editable mode:

Verify your development installation:

title: Contribute > Testing
text:
Testing

This project takes advantage of tox. This tool lets you automate common
development tasks (similar to Makefile), but it is oriented towards Python
development.

title: Contribute > Use tox
text:
Use tox

As Makefile has rules, tox has environments. In fact, the tool creates its
own virtual environment so that anything being tested is isolated from the project
to guarantee the project’s integrity.

The following environment commands are provided:

tox -e style: Checks for coding style quality.

tox -e py: Checks for unit tests.

tox -e py-coverage: Checks for unit testing and code coverage.

tox -e doc: Checks for the documentation-building process.

title: Contribute > Perform raw testing
text:
Perform raw testing

If required, from the command line, you can always call style commands, such as
Black, isort, and Flake8, or unit testing commands such as pytest. However,
running these commands does not guarantee that your project is being tested in an isolated
environment, which is the reason why tools like tox exist.

title: Contribute > Use pre-commit
text:
Use pre-commit

The style checks take advantage of pre-commit. Developers are not forced but
encouraged to install this tool by running this command:

title: Contribute > Documentation
text:
Documentation

To build documentation, you can run the usual rules provided in the
Sphinx Makefile:

However, the recommended way of checking documentation integrity is to use tox:

title: Contribute > Distribution
text:
Distribution

If you would like to create source or wheel files, run these commands to
install the building requirements and then execute the build module:

title: Examples
text:
Examples

This section shows how to use PyConceptEV.

title: Examples > Basic usage examples
text:
Basic usage examples

These examples show how to use PyConcentEV to perform basic operations.

Examples require access to ConceptEV software as a service.

/auto_examples/01_simple_workflow

/auto_examples/02_get_results_workflow

/auto_examples/03_bulk_job_submit



Gallery generated by Sphinx-Gallery

title: User guide
text:
User guide

This section explains how to use PyConceptEV.

title: User guide > Create a client
text:
Create a client

Create a client that can access and talk to the Ansys ConceptEV API. You can use
the health check endpoint to check your connection.
The token is cached within a file called token_cache.bin you can configure the cache location with
an argument to the get_http_client function cache_filepath.

title: User guide > Update configuration
text:
Update configuration

Update the configuration of the client by using the config.toml the defaults are located in src/ansys/conceptev/core/resources/config.toml.
Create a new config.toml file in your working directory with the account_name set or create an environment variable called ACCOUNT_NAME and the settings management should find it.
Most things can be left as default but the account_name should be changed to match your company account name.

title: User guide > Configure SSL certificate for company networks
text:
Configure SSL certificate for company networks

If you’re working behind a corporate firewall or need to use custom SSL certificates, you can configure PyConceptEV to use a custom PEM certificate file instead of the default certificate bundle.

Option 1: Using environment variable (recommended)

Set the SSL_CERT_FILE environment variable to point to your custom certificate file:

Option 2: Using config.toml file

Add the ssl_cert_file setting to your config.toml:

Creating a custom certificate bundle

If your company provides a custom CA certificate, you may need to combine it with the default certificates:

Then set the SSL_CERT_FILE environment variable or ssl_cert_file config option to point to your custom-bundle.pem file.

Note: If no custom SSL certificate is configured, PyConceptEV uses the default certificate bundle provided by the certifi package.

title: Bulk Job Submit.
text:
Bulk Job Submit.

Example Script to bulk submit jobs to the ConceptEV API.
This example copies the template into a project and runs a number of jobs with different
combinations of components.
The combinations of components are specified in a CSV file format.

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Perform Required imports
text: Perform Required imports

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Set up inputs.
text:
Set up inputs.

Change the following variables to match your data.
The current filename for combinations can be used as an example.
The current base_concept_id is a template concept that will be copied.
Component Order is dictionary that maps the column names in the combinations file to the
component names in the API.

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Create a client and create a new project from template.
text:
Create a client and create a new project from template.

Authenticate and get a token
Create an API client.
Get the account ID and HPC ID.
Copy the template into a new project.
Add a clutch to the concept.
Get the component IDs for the new concept.
Get the architecture for the new concept.

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Read combinations from a csv file and check they match the combinations file.
text:
Read combinations from a csv file and check they match the combinations file.

Read combinations from a csv file.
Get the component types from the component_order dictionary.
Turn them into set.
Check that the component types are in the combinations file.
Get the component names from the combinations.
Check the component names are in the base components.

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Submit jobs for each combination.
text:
Submit jobs for each combination.

Create a new design instance with title.
Create an output list to store the created designs.
Copy the base Concept into that new design instance.
Get the component IDs for the new design instance as they change when copied.
Change the base concept to use the new components.
Update the architecture on the server.
Update the local concept instance with the new architecture id.
Create and submit a job using the new concept (with the new architecture).

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Save the list of created designs to a file.
text:
Save the list of created designs to a file.

Create a pandas dataframe.
Export to Excel.

title: Bulk Job Submit. > Delete the extra project on the server.
text:
Delete the extra project on the server.

Delete the project on the server.

This will delete the project and all its contents.
Only needed for keep test environment clean.

Total running time of the script: (0 minutes 25.886 seconds)

title: Simple workflow
text:
Simple workflow

This example shows how to use PyConcentEV to perform basic operations.
- Required imports
- Define example data
- Get a token from Ansys ID
- Use API client for the Ansys ConceptEV service

title: Simple workflow > Perform Required imports
text: Perform Required imports

title: Simple workflow > Define example data
text:
Define example data

You can obtain example data from the schema sections of the API documentation.

title: Simple workflow > Use API client for the Ansys ConceptEV service
text:
Use API client for the Ansys ConceptEV service

Use the API client to perform basic operations on the Ansys ConceptEV service.
Such as:
- Check api connection is healthy.
- Get the account ID and HPC ID.
- Create a new project.
- Create a new concept within that project.

title: Simple workflow > Perform basic operations
text:
Perform basic operations

Perform basic operations on the design instance associated with the new project.
Such as:
- Create configurations.
- Create components.
- Create architectures.
- Create requirements.
- Create and submit a job.
- Read the results and show the result in your browser.

title: Simple workflow > Delete the extra project on the server.
text:
Delete the extra project on the server.

Delete the project on the server.

This will delete the project and all its contents.
Only needed for keep test environment clean.

Total running time of the script: (0 minutes 50.918 seconds)

title: PyConceptEV documentation 0.10.dev0
text:
PyConceptEV documentation 0.10.dev0

PyConceptEV is a Python client library for the Ansys ConceptEV
service, which provides a cloud-based design and simulation platform for the concept design
of EV powertrains.

Getting started 

Learn how to install PyConceptEV in user mode and quickly
begin using it.

getting_started

User guide 

Learn how to configure a PyConceptEV session, get a token, and
create a client.

user_guide

API reference 

Understand how the Ansys ConceptEV API documentation
provides for interacting programmatically with PyConcept EV.

api_ref

Examples 

Explore examples that show how to use PyConcept EV.

auto_examples/index

Contribute 

Learn how to to contribute to the PyConceptEV codebase or documentation.

contributing

title: Get Results workflow
text:
Get Results workflow

This example shows how to use PyConcentEV to get a list of result parameters
from a list of design_instance_ids
These lists are provided in design_instance_ids.csv

Assumes a front and rear motor architecture.
Assumes a specific drive cycle result is available.
If short results is true it gets in User Units
Assumes first job in list for each project is the result we want.

title: Get Results workflow > Perform required imports
text:
Perform required imports

Get the necessary imports.

title: Get Results workflow > Inputs
text:
Inputs

Change the following variables to match your data.

title: Get Results workflow > Generate and run templates
text:
Generate and run templates

This function generates a new project and runs a template for each design_instance_id
The design_instance_ids are returned for later use.

title: Get Results workflow > Create a client and set up projects
text:
Create a client and set up projects

Generates and runs templates

title: Get Results workflow > Get the project results
text:
Get the project results

This code gets the project results from the ConceptEV API.

title: Get Results workflow > Get the project results from a list of design_instance_ids
text:
Get the project results from a list of design_instance_ids

This code gets the project results from a list of design instance ids.

title: Get Results workflow > Get component name from project results.
text:
Get component name from project results.

This code gets the component name from the project results.

title: Get Results workflow > Get results for a drive cycle requirement.
text:
Get results for a drive cycle requirement.

Get the results for a drive cycle requirement.

title: Get Results workflow > Getting all the results.
text:
Getting all the results.

First get results of the server or load from file.

title: Get Results workflow > Output the results to Excel File.
text:
Output the results to Excel File.

Create an output results list to store outputs.
Loop through all results.
Get the data we want to output.
Place in a records list for each row of Excel file.

title: Get Results workflow > Output the results to Excel File.
text:
Output the results to Excel File.

Convert the output results to a pandas DataFrame.
Output the results to an Excel file.

title: API reference
text:
API reference

The Ansys ConceptEV API documentation
shows you which verbs and which routes or paths are available and what inputs
and outputs they have. You can use the verb functions in this API to make
things simpler.

To create a configuration, you must use the verb POST with the route /configurations
and add the data object from the schema:

title: Getting started
text:
Getting started

This section describes how to install PyConceptEV in user mode and
quickly begin using it. If you are interested in contributing to PyConceptEV,
see ref_contributing for information on installing in developer mode.

title: Getting started > Installation
text:
Installation

Before installing PyConceptEV, make sure that you have the latest version
of pip by running this command:

Then, install PyConceptEV with this command:

title: Getting started > Optional dependencies
text:
Optional dependencies

To install the optional dependencies to run the examples script:

If you are using Linux and want to use the encryption features, you need to install
the optional dependencies for Linux encryption. For example on Debian Linux you need:

Other dependency groups are specified in the pyproject.toml file.
